message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Myosin-binding protein C is typically found in cardiac myocytes and mutations in this gene have been associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The sudden death of the patient's father during exercise is consistent with this diagnosis. The likely finding on histological evaluation of his heart at autopsy would be myocyte disarray, a characteristic feature of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Amyloid deposits are associated with amyloidosis, eosinophilic infiltration is associated with eosinophilic myocarditis, and wavy myocytes are associated with arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy, all of which are less likely given the patient's family history and clinical presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The autosomal dominant mutation in myosin-binding protein C is associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, specifically myocyte disarray. The sudden death while running suggests a cardiac event. Amyloid deposits and eosinophilic infiltration are not associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and wavy myocytes are more commonly seen in arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. An autosomal dominant mutation in myosin-binding protein C is associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The sudden death while exercising suggests ventricular arrhythmia, which is often linked to myocyte disarray in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Amyloid deposits are more common in restrictive cardiomyopathy, eosinophilic infiltration is more common in eosinophilic myocarditis, and wavy myocytes are more common in arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The autosomal dominant mutation in myosin-binding protein C suggests hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which is commonly associated with myocyte disarray on histological evaluation of the heart at autopsy. Amyloid deposits are associated with amyloidosis, eosinophilic infiltration with hypereosinophilic syndrome, and wavy myocytes with arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia/cardiomyopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Autosomal dominant mutations in myosin-binding protein C are associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which can lead to sudden death in young athletes. The likely histological finding on autopsy of her father's heart would be myocyte disarray. Amyloid deposits and eosinophilic infiltration are not typically associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and wavy myocytes are typically seen in arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia/cardiomyopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The autosomal dominant mutation in myosin-binding protein C is associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). HCM is characterized by myocyte disarray, which is a histological finding commonly seen on autopsy in individuals with this condition. Amyloid deposits are seen in amyloidosis, eosinophilic infiltration may be seen in eosinophilic myocarditis, and wavy myocytes may be seen in arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy, but none of these are associated with the mentioned mutation in myosin-binding protein C.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has an autosomal dominant mutation in myosin-binding protein C, which is associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Sudden cardiac death is a common complication of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. On histological evaluation of the father's heart at autopsy, myocyte disarray is the most likely finding associated with the disease. Amyloid deposits are seen in restrictive cardiomyopathy, eosinophilic infiltration is seen in eosinophilic myocarditis, and wavy myocytes are associated with arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Autosomal dominant mutation in myosin-binding protein C is associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and sudden death during physical activity is a known complication. The likely finding on histological evaluation of her father's heart at autopsy would be myocyte disarray. Amyloid deposits and eosinophilic infiltration are not specifically associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and wavy myocytes are more commonly seen in arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The autosomal dominant mutation in myosin-binding protein C suggests that the father had hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), which is associated with myocyte disarray on histological evaluation at autopsy, as well as other structural changes such as hypertrophied ventricular walls and abnormal mitral valve function. Amyloid deposits are seen in cardiac amyloidosis, eosinophilic infiltration is seen in eosinophilic myocarditis, and wavy myocytes are seen in arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy, but these conditions are not associated with HCM.

We refer to the medical textbook "Genetics and Genomics in Medicine" by Tom Strachan and Judith Goodship for help. Myosin-binding protein C mutations are associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which causes myocyte disarray on histological evaluation. Sudden death while exercising is a common occurrence in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Amyloid deposits are associated with amyloidosis, eosinophilic infiltration with eosinophilic myocarditis, and wavy myocytes with arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy, but these are not associated with myosin-binding protein C mutations.
